Activity: High tempo of terrorist activity across Africa; consolidation into parallel authority systems in weak/contested rural and borderland areas.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AUCTC mandate; APSA; PSC Protocol (counter-terrorism coordination)
Main Objective: Provide continent-wide threat assessment highlighting lethality and governance impacts.
Target Beneficiary: AU policy organs; Member States; RECs/RMs; security stakeholders
Outcome: Threat characterized by increasing parallel governance functions by terrorist groups.

Activity: Key continental CT/VE trends: Sahel territorial expansion & spillover; crime–terror linkages (illicit mining, fuel, narcotics, kidnapping-for-ransom, maritime crime); emerging tech (drones, encrypted comms, AI-generated propaganda, crypto finance); convergence with UCG and political fragmentation.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AUCTC mandate; APSA; PSC guidance on CT/VE
Main Objective: Identify cross-cutting trends shaping CT/VE threat environment and operational requirements.
Target Beneficiary: AU/RECs/RMs; security and justice institutions; partners
Outcome: Evidence base for integrated approaches and tech/finance countermeasures.

Activity: Sahel assessed as epicentre; Mali–Burkina Faso–Niger treated as interconnected insecurity ecosystem; intensified JNIM and ISSP competition/expansion (estimated >3,000 fighters).
Main Objective: Track regional threat dynamics and force posture of key extremist actors.
Target Beneficiary: Sahel Member States; RECs/RMs; AU PSC
Outcome: Structural erosion of state authority; theatres increasingly linked to coastal West Africa.

Activity: Burkina Faso large areas outside Ouagadougou under de facto extremist influence; Niger border corridors contested; extremist mobility links Sahel to coastal West Africa.
Main Objective: Assess extent of territorial influence and spillover risk.
Outcome: Signals deepening structural insecurity and increased cross-border mobility.

Activity: Mali: JNIM economic warfare and coercive encirclement of Bamako by interdicting fuel/supply routes (notably from Senegal and Côte d’Ivoire), leading to nationwide fuel crisis and secondary impacts.
Main Objective: Monitor high-risk scenario indicators and cascading socio-economic impacts.
Target Beneficiary: Government and population of Mali; regional partners
Outcome: Fuel crisis triggered school closures, economic contraction, and reduced diplomatic presence.

Activity: AUCTC early-warning outlook: if trajectories persist, 2026 may see prolonged isolation or partial takeover of a Sahelian capital by non-state armed actors/terrorist groups; calls for more coherent regional approach.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AUCTC; CEWS linkage; PSC guidance on early warning/early action
Main Objective: Flag potential high-impact scenarios requiring preventive diplomacy and coordinated response.
Outcome: Early-warning triggers emphasize need for inclusive regional cooperation to address root causes.

Activity: Spillover into Gulf of Guinea: Benin, Togo, Ghana, Côte d’Ivoire infiltration along forested borderlands, artisanal mining zones and marginalized coastal communities; strategy to secure logistics hubs, recruitment pools, maritime trafficking access.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AUCTC analysis and regional coordination mandate
Main Objective: Assess southward expansion vectors and protection needs for coastal states.
Target Beneficiary: Coastal West African Member States; communities
Outcome: Indicators point to deliberate logistics and maritime-access strategy by extremist networks.

Activity: Other theatres: ISWAP & Boko Haram resilient around Lake Chad via control of local economic ecosystems; ADF/ISCAP entrenched in illicit minerals in eastern DRC; Al‑Shabaab maintains fiscal autonomy, territorial depth and cross-border reach.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AUCTC analysis mandate; AU counter-terrorism frameworks
Main Objective: Provide multi-theatre threat update to inform AU/REC action.
Country: Nigeria; Niger; Chad; Cameroon; DRC; Somalia
Outcome: Confirms continued resilience and sophistication of multiple extremist organizations.

Activity: Structural drivers underpinning CT/VE: governance fragility; youth marginalization; climate stress/displacement; crime–terror nexuses; weaponized information ecosystems/digital manipulation.
Main Objective: Highlight structural prevention priorities beyond kinetic responses.
Outcome: Reinforces need for systemic interventions addressing root causes.

Activity: Normalization of technology-enabled terrorism: drones, encrypted platforms, AI-generated propaganda/disinformation, crypto-assets & mobile money financing; disinformation intersects with elections and communal tensions.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AUCTC; CEWS; relevant AU cyber/digital frameworks
Main Objective: Assess emerging-technology threat vectors and implications for CT operations and electoral security.
Outcome: Complicates CT operations and erodes public trust; increases need for digital resilience.

Activity: Consultative validation workshop (expert level) adopted the Draft Continental Strategic Plan of Action on Countering Terrorism in Africa (2026–2030 framework) at AUCTC HQ in Algiers with RECs/RMs.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AUCTC mandate; AU procedures for strategic plans
Main Objective: Validate strategic pillars, operational priorities and monitoring architecture against regional realities before political endorsement.
Outcome: Technically robust and implementation-ready draft prepared for submission for political adoption.

Activity: Commissioning of Continental Study on implementation of WPS in Africa (25th anniversary of UNSCR 1325) in partnership with UN Women, GIZ and NeTT4Peace.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: UNSCR 1325; AU WPS framework; PSC directives
Main Objective: Provide evidence-based evaluation of 25 years of WPS progress, gaps and recommendations (policy, financing, accountability).
Target Beneficiary: AU, Member States, RECs, partners; women and girls affected by conflict
Outcome: Study to inform forward-looking WPS policy and programming amid emerging threats (digital insecurity, climate, violent extremism).
Unit: Office of Special Envoy on WPS (OSE-WPS)

Activity: Regional consultations grounding the Continental WPS Study, including five regional dialogues integrating CSOs, women’s networks and academia.
Main Objective: Ensure inclusive evidence base and diverse perspectives for WPS study; respond to PSC directives on collaborative platforms.
Outcome: Inclusive consultations completed to inform study findings and recommendations.

Activity: Inter-Continental Knowledge Exchange & Dialogue in Algiers launched the Annual AU Forum on Women in Security Sector Leadership; also advanced Community of Practice on Integrating Gender in Early Warning Systems with RECs.
Main Objective: Advance women’s meaningful participation in military/police leadership and institutionalize gender integration in early warning.
Target Beneficiary: Member States; RECs; security sector institutions; early warning actors
Outcome: Flagship annual forum launched; preventive capabilities strengthened through gender-in-early-warning community of practice.

Activity: High-level Windhoek meeting hosted by Namibia to mark 25th anniversary of UNSCR 1325; adopted Windhoek+25 Declaration.
Main Objective: Reaffirm commitments to institutionalize women’s roles in peace processes, predictable financing, youth engagement, and gender integration including climate security.
Outcome: Windhoek+25 Declaration adopted as forward-looking framework for next 25 years of WPS in Africa.

Activity: Nigeria WPS recovery initiative: vocational training and start-up equipment for 250 women in conflict-affected communities in Maiduguri.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: UNSCR 1325 NAP support; AU WPS recovery pillar
Main Objective: Support relief/recovery pillar of UNSCR 1325 NAPs via livelihoods model ('training + tools') to enhance resilience.
Outcome: Livelihoods strengthened; end-of-year assessment planned to document replicable impact model.

Activity: Guinea Conakry WPS localization project mobilizing religious/traditional leaders, media, and youth networks to promote women’s participation in governance.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: UNSCR 1325 NAP support; AU WPS agenda
Main Objective: Localize UNSCR 1325 NAPs and strengthen grassroots ecosystem supporting women’s participation.
Outcome: Grassroots support mobilized to increase women’s participation and protection.

Activity: Launch of Digital Continental Results reporting platform for Member States to report on WPS NAP implementation (for 2024 reporting).
Main Objective: Facilitate easier and effective reporting and accountability on WPS NAP implementation.
Outcome: Digital reporting platform operational to strengthen WPS accountability and learning.

Activity: 6th High-Level Africa Forum on Women, Peace and Security convened with Tunisia; adopted Tunis Declaration and Call to Action.
Main Objective: Commemorate 25th anniversary of UNSCR 1325 and strengthen WPS implementation; promote operationalization of OSE-WPS.
Target Beneficiary: Member States; AU; partners; WPS stakeholders
Outcome: Tunis Declaration adopted; call to strengthen OSE-WPS structures/resources/mandate.

Activity: Expansion of YPS National Action Plans: Burundi, Malawi, The Gambia, Liberia, Cameroon launched YPS NAPs (joining DRC and Nigeria; total 7).

Country: Burundi; Malawi; The Gambia; Liberia; Cameroon; DRC; Nigeria

Activity: Validation of Guidelines for Development of YPS NAPs through PSC Committee of Experts.

Outcome: Guidelines validated to strengthen national implementation capacity.

Activity: Youth participation in AU Election Observation Missions: ~30% of observers were young people (including AYAPs); WiseYouth members deployed to preventive diplomacy missions in electoral contexts.

Activity: First Sudanese Youth Dialogue Forum hosted in Kampala, Uganda, to inform the Inter-Sudanese political process.

Activity: Validation of Operational Guidance Note (OGN) on Operationalising Child-Sensitive Early Warning to integrate child indicators into CEWS.

Activity: Review of AU Child Protection Harmonised Curriculum (2019) aligned with AU Policy on Child Protection in Peace Support Operations (2022).

Main Objective: Update training to address gaps in scope/methodology and ensure comprehensive child protection training for missions.

Activity: Capacity-building for CSOs on child-sensitive, trauma-informed reintegration/rehabilitation of CAAFAG; and for mediation support experts (FemWise, WiseYouth, CSOs) to integrate child protection into mediation; validated proposed AU Guidelines for Child Participation in Mediation and Peace Processes.

Activity: Support to three PSC Open Sessions: combating recruitment of children; rehabilitation/reintegration of CAAFAG; protection of children in armed conflict.

Main Objective: Elevate political engagement and reinforce Member State obligations on child protection.

Activity: Launch of reaffirmation of Ghana–Côte d’Ivoire shared land boundary through placement of boundary marker (ceremony in Newtown, Ghana).

Main Objective: Finalize coherent, implementable CAP-CPS framework under PSC guidance.

Activity: Member States Validation Workshop on draft CAP-CPS in Nairobi; agreed roadmap for further refinement prior to final validation and submission to PSC.
Main Objective: Validate and refine CAP-CPS with Member State ownership and alignment with national/regional contexts.
Outcome: Roadmap agreed; further refinement planned before final validation and submission.

Activity: 2nd Africa Climate Summit held in Addis Ababa; adopted Addis Ababa Climate Declaration highlighting climate–peace–security nexus.
Main Objective: Elevate political commitment and link climate action to peace and security risks.

Activity: Peace Fund Crisis Reserve Facility (carryover USD 7m) disbursed: USD 1m for DRC mediation/facilitation (merged Luanda & Nairobi); USD 1m for LCBC/MNJTF stabilisation tools; USD 1m for South Sudan stabilisation; USD 1m for Mozambique counter-terrorism reconstruction machinery; USD 0.5m for Niger emergency food support; USD 0.5m for Mali early recovery/vocational training.

Country: DRC; Lake Chad Basin; South Sudan; Mozambique; Niger; Mali
Outcome: CRF resources applied across mediation, stabilisation, reconstruction and humanitarian support interventions.

Activity: PRC approved 37 Peace Fund Pilot Projects covering 15 priority areas (USD 5m) across Preventive Diplomacy & Mediation, Institutional Capacity, and AU PSOs windows.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AU Peace Fund (three windows) and PRC approval
Main Objective: Operationalize Peace Fund through complementary pilot projects across all five regions.
Target Beneficiary: AU organs; Member States; RECs/RMs; PSOs
Outcome: Peace Fund poised for full operationalization with pilot projects complementing regular budget and CRF.

Activity: Executive Council agreed to increase Peace Fund CRF ceiling by USD 10m (from Peace Fund interest), raising 2025 allocation to USD 20m in support to AUSSOM.
Main Objective: Strengthen predictable financing support to AUSSOM via Peace Fund CRF.
Outcome: CRF ceiling increased; allocation raised to USD 20m for AUSSOM support.

Activity: CEWS enhanced data collection/monitoring through automated event tracking; deepened collaboration with RECs/RMs and APRM; strengthened staff capacity-building.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: Article 12 PSC Protocol; Continental Structural Conflict Prevention Framework (CSCPF)
Main Objective: Improve analytical, coordination and prevention functions of CEWS (Article 12 PSC Protocol; CSCPF).
Outcome: Improved information exchange and joint analytical outputs.

Activity: CEWS strategic upgrade: updated analytical frameworks/indicators; AI-assisted analysis; exploration of GIS-based risk mapping; joint analytical mechanisms with AUCTC and other AU organs.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: Article 12 PSC Protocol; CEWS reform agenda
Main Objective: Modernize CEWS tools and coordination mechanisms while maintaining core operations.
Outcome: Transition toward upgraded CEWS design, tools and inter-agency coordination.

Activity: Support to Member States on structural prevention: rollout of Country Structural Vulnerability and Resilience Assessments (CSVRA) and Country Structural Vulnerability Mitigation Strategies (CSVMS); CSVRA validated in Malawi; CSVRA/CSVMS report launched in Zambia.
Main Objective: Strengthen national early warning systems and national peace infrastructures through structural vulnerability assessments and mitigation strategies.
Target Beneficiary: Member States; national early warning/peace infrastructures
Outcome: Improved national capacities for risk monitoring, response options and embedding early warning in governance/policy.

Activity: PSC 1298th meeting received CEWS briefing on “Mapping Risks and Threats”; communiqué called for robust, coherent, fully functional CEWS.
Main Objective: Inform PSC deliberations and strengthen early action through CEWS risk mapping.
Outcome: PSC emphasized urgent need for fully functional CEWS and coordinated early action.

Activity: PSC 1303rd meeting underscored urgent need to revamp CEWS; deplored denialism toward early warning findings; requested mechanism to address; emphasized Integrated Preventive Diplomacy and Action framework linking CEWS with RECs/RMs, Panel of the Wise, APRM, AFRIPOL, AUCTC and CISSA.
Main Objective: Strengthen early warning-to-early action and inter-agency collaboration; address denialism and institutionalize integrated preventive diplomacy.
Target Beneficiary: AU PSC; Member States; AU organs and RECs/RMs
Outcome: Clear direction for CEWS reform and integrated framework across AU prevention actors.

Activity: AU NeTT4Peace delivered policy recommendation on “New Vision for Disarmament for the AU”.
Main Objective: Provide strategic insights to guide AU efforts in weapons control and non-proliferation.
Target Beneficiary: AU policy organs; Member States; research community
Outcome: Evidence-based recommendation produced to inform policy and decision-making.

Activity: NeTT4Peace co-organized workshop on peace operations (with CCCPA) in preparation for Aswan Forum for Sustainable Peace and Development (Aswan).
Main Objective: Support policy dialogue and capacity-building on peace operations; feed into Aswan Forum and AU High-Level Retreat.
Target Beneficiary: AU stakeholders; partners; peace operations practitioners
Outcome: Policy dialogue supported; inputs to Aswan Forum/retreat processes strengthened.

Activity: NeTT4Peace supported a 3-Day Youth–Wise Learning Experience on Transitional Justice and Genocide in Johannesburg, South Africa.
Main Objective: Empower youth as agents for sustainable peace through intergenerational learning on transitional justice/genocide prevention.
Outcome: Youth capacity strengthened; intergenerational learning advanced.

Activity: AU I‑RECKE Fourth Policy Session on Early Warning and Conflict Prevention held in Malabo (margins of 7th Mid-Year Coordination Meeting); endorsed Joint AU–RECs/RMs Resource Mobilisation Strategy.
Main Objective: Exchange lessons on structural conflict prevention; address early warning-to-early action bottlenecks; secure sustainable coordinated funding.
Outcome: Resource mobilisation strategy endorsed; lessons shared on closing early warning-response gap and inclusive prevention.

Activity: Hybrid Technical Assessment of ICGLR carried out by AUC with AU Liaison Office in Burundi to evaluate eligibility for recognition as AU Regional Mechanism (RM).
Main Objective: Evaluate ICGLR institutional/operational/technical capacities and alignment with AU policy frameworks to inform AU recognition process.
Target Beneficiary: ICGLR Secretariat; AU policy organs; Great Lakes stakeholders
Outcome: Assessment recommended considering formal request for AU recognition as regional cooperation partner.

Activity: UN–AU Experts Group meeting on AI, conflict analysis and early warning held in Addis Ababa with RECs/RMs and youth; produced draft roadmap for AI-enhanced CEWS and advanced analytical dashboard.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: Joint UN–AU Framework for Enhanced Partnership in Peace and Security
Main Objective: Build understanding and roadmap for applying AI to CEWS while ensuring data sovereignty and security.
Outcome: Draft AI roadmap developed (advanced dashboard and in-house data infrastructure).

Activity: 25th AU‑UN Joint Task Force on Peace and Security held on margins of UNGA; reviewed partnership and joint framework implementation (DRC, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, West Africa).
Main Objective: Maintain institutional dialogue and coordination on priority situations and mission financing.
Target Beneficiary: AU and UN institutions; Member States in focus contexts
Outcome: Partnership reviewed; financing of AU-led PSOs central theme incl. UNSCR 2719 implementation.

Activity: 9th Annual Conference in New York on AU–UN cooperation discussed UNSCR 2719 financing plus financing for development, climate action and WPS.
Main Objective: Advance strategic partnership and financing dialogue for AU-led peace operations and cross-cutting agendas.
Outcome: Integrated discussions reinforced financing and thematic linkages.

Activity: 10th Informal Joint Seminar and 19th Annual Joint Consultative Meeting between AU PSC and UN Security Council held in Addis Ababa; monthly coordination between AU PSC Chair and UNSC President continues.
Main Objective: Enhance complementary action and information exchange; advocate for predictable financing for AU PSOs.
Outcome: Regularized AU–UNSC coordination deepened; practical means for complementary action advanced.

Activity: Conclusion of EU-APSA IV programme strengthening institutional capacity, early warning, inclusive peacebuilding (civil society, youth, child protection).
Main Objective: Support APSA capacity and inclusive approaches to peacebuilding and early warning.
Target Beneficiary: AU; RECs/RMs; civil society; youth; children affected by conflict
Outcome: Institutional capacities strengthened; inclusive peacebuilding supported.

Activity: Finalised successor EU Governance, Peace and Security (EU-GPS) Programme (2026–2029) supporting APSA and AGA in integrated manner (early warning, prevention, mediation, climate/security, human rights, governance/democracy).
Main Objective: Provide integrated support to governance, peace and security priorities with stronger human rights and citizen participation focus.
Outcome: New integrated programme framework ready for implementation 2026–2029.

Activity: Early Response Mechanism (ERM III) scheduled to conclude 31 December 2025; AU–EU agreed transition of functions to support Peace Fund CRF with technical assistance.
Mandate Authorising Activity (PSC/Assemb: AU Peace Fund CRF; AU–EU financing cooperation
Main Objective: Shift crisis response financing toward sustainable, internally driven model anchored in AU Peace Fund CRF.
Target Beneficiary: AU; Member States; crisis response mechanisms
Outcome: Transition plan aligns ERM functions with CRF support.

Activity: New Joint Framework Arrangement (formerly Joint Financing Arrangement) finalised; EU moved from observer to signatory; coordination mechanism for planning, budgeting and joint reviews.
Main Objective: Strengthen harmonised planning/budgeting and predictable partner support through coordinated reviews and reporting.
Outcome: Framework supports information sharing and results-oriented coordination.

Activity: TICAD 9 Summit in Yokohama: Commissioner for PAPS delivered statement linking peace, security and development; highlighted AUSSOM, mediation and PCRD; called for partnership against disinformation and for sustainable financing.
Main Objective: Engage strategic partner (Japan) on peace/stability agenda and emerging threats; promote African-led solutions and financing.
Outcome: Partnership messages advanced; emphasis on preventive diplomacy and sustainable financing reinforced.

Activity: PAPS advanced department-wide Knowledge Management Strategy; implemented interim measures to strengthen knowledge flows; planned enhancements to digital repository with TfP; produced PCRD Journal (2nd edition) and Common African Position on Peacebuilding Architecture Review; undertook lessons learned studies and Peace Dividends publication.
Main Objective: Institutionalise learning to inform policy formulation, planning and PSC decision-making/oversight across APSA/AGA.
Target Beneficiary: PAPS directorates; AU PSC; Member States
Outcome: Knowledge products and lessons learned strengthened evidence base for PSC deliberations and reforms.

Activity: AU PSC Field Visit to Mali
Main Objective: Assess political transition and demonstrate AU solidarity
